The reception for Korean War veterans was different than for World War II veterans for several reasons. Firstly, the Korean War was a relatively short conflict, lasting from 1950 to 1953, while World War II lasted for six years and involved a much larger number of soldiers. As a result, the Korean War did not have the same level of public support and involvement as World War II, and it did not have the same impact on the American psyche.

Secondly, the Korean War was fought during the early years of the Cold War, and it was seen as a "limited war" fought to contain the spread of communism rather than a war fought for a clear and noble purpose like World War II. This made it harder for Americans to rally behind the war effort and to feel a sense of pride and accomplishment in their service.

Thirdly, the Korean War was not officially declared a war by Congress, but rather was considered a "police action" or a "conflict." This meant that Korean War veterans were not eligible for the same benefits and recognition as World War II veterans, such as the GI Bill and the World War II Victory Medal.

Finally, the homecoming for Korean War veterans was not as celebratory or welcoming as it was for World War II veterans. The Korean War ended in a stalemate, with no clear victor or resolution, and there was not the same sense of closure or triumph that came with the end of World War II. Additionally, many Korean War veterans returned home to a society that was more focused on the consumerism and prosperity of the post-war era than on honoring their service and sacrifice. As a result, Korean War veterans were often overlooked or forgotten in the years following the war.
